concept.title: Example: content reference and the xml:lang attribute
concept.shortdesc: This scenario outlines how processors determine the effective value of the xml:lang attribute for content that is referenced by the conref or conkeyref attribute.

draft-comment.author: Kristen J Eberlein
draft-comment.p: This scenario kind of exemplifies an edge case of an edge case ... I don't know how many examples of xml:lang we need, but this one seems very contrived.

conbody.p: In this example, a DITA topic specifies an xml:lang attribute of en. However, it contains content that is conrefed from a element that explicitly sets the xml:lang attribute to fr.

conbody.p: Note that the value of the xml:lang attribute of the referenced note is set by the containing section element that sets the xml:lang attribute to fr. When the topic that contained the conrefed note is processed, the note element with the id attribute set to mynote has an effective value for the xml:lang attribute of fr.
